territories.name: Andaman & Nicobar Islands
territories.history: The Andaman and Nicobar Islands are a group of 572 islands located in the Bay of Bengal. These islands were historically used as penal settlements by the British, the most infamous being Cellular Jail (Kala Pani) in Port Blair. During World War II, the islands were occupied by the Japanese and were briefly administered by Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose in 1943 under the Azad Hind Government. After independence, the islands became a Union Territory in 1956. Today, they are a strategic military location and a hub for eco-tourism and marine biodiversity.

touristPlaces.name: Radhanagar Beach
touristPlaces.description: Voted as Asia's best beach with white sands and turquoise waters
touristPlaces.significance: Ranked #7 in world's best beaches by Time Magazine

touristPlaces.name: Cellular Jail
touristPlaces.description: Historic colonial prison used by British to exile freedom fighters

territories.name: Delhi
territories.history: Delhi has been a historical capital of India across centuries, ruled by Mauryas, Mughals, Delhi Sultanate, and British. It became the capital of British India in 1911, replacing Calcutta. After independence, it was a Union Territory and later given partial statehood under the 69th Constitutional Amendment Act in 1991, making it the National Capital Territory (NCT). Delhi has its own elected government, but key areas like law and order remain under central control. It houses the President, Prime Minister, Parliament, and Supreme Court.

touristPlaces.name: Red Fort
touristPlaces.description: 17th-century Mughal fort and UNESCO World Heritage Site
touristPlaces.significance: Prime Minister addresses nation from here on Independence Day

territories.name: Puducherry
territories.tagline: The French Riviera of the East

facts.famousFood: French cuisine, Creole dishes, Filter Coffee

territories.history: Puducherry was a French colony until 1954, when it was de facto transferred to India (de jure in 1962). It consists of four unconnected districts: Puducherry, Karaikal (Tamil Nadu), Mahe (Kerala), and Yanam (Andhra Pradesh). Puducherry retains a strong French cultural influence, seen in its architecture, food, and street names. It is a Union Territory with a legislature, one of only three in India (along with Delhi and Jammu & Kashmir).

touristPlaces.name: Auroville
touristPlaces.description: Experimental township focused on human unity

territories.name: Chandigarh

facts.famousFood: Butter Chicken, Chole Bhature, Amritsari Kulcha

territories.history: Chandigarh was created as a planned city after Partition in 1947, when Lahore became part of Pakistan. It was designed by French architect Le Corbusier and serves as a model of urban planning and architecture. It became a Union Territory in 1966, after Punjab was bifurcated into Punjab and Haryana. Interestingly, Chandigarh functions as the capital of both Punjab and Haryana, but is not part of either state. It is known for its greenery, cleanliness, and modern infrastructure.

touristPlaces.name: Rock Garden
touristPlaces.description: 40-acre sculpture garden made from industrial waste
touristPlaces.significance: Created by Nek Chand from recycled materials

territories.name: Ladakh
territories.history: Ladakh was part of the state of Jammu and Kashmir until 2019, when it was carved out as a separate Union Territory. It includes the districts of Leh and Kargil and is known for its Buddhist heritage, high-altitude deserts, and strategic military significance due to its borders with China (LAC) and Pakistan (LoC). Though it lacks a legislature, it has Autonomous Hill Development Councils in both districts to ensure regional representation and development.

touristPlaces.name: Nubra Valley
touristPlaces.description: High altitude cold desert with double-humped camels

territories.name: Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu
territories.tagline: Twin Territories of Sun, Sea and Sand

facts.famousFood: Seafood Curry, Pork Vindaloo, Bebinca (Goan dessert)

territories.history: Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu is a Union Territory formed by merging two former Portuguese territories—Dadra and Nagar Haveli, which was liberated by Indian nationalists in 1954, and Daman and Diu, which was annexed by India in 1961 during Operation Vijay, along with Goa. These regions, despite their geographical separation and distinct cultural influences, were merged on January 26, 2020, to improve administrative efficiency. The Union Territory retains a strong Portuguese colonial legacy, visible in its architecture, churches, language influence, and traditional festivals.

touristPlaces.name: Diu Fort
touristPlaces.description: 16th-century Portuguese fort with sea views and cannons.

touristPlaces.name: Silvassa
touristPlaces.description: Capital of Dadra & Nagar Haveli with tribal museums and waterfalls.

touristPlaces.name: Jampore Beach, Daman
touristPlaces.description: Pristine beach with black sand and Portuguese-era churches nearby.

territories.name: Lakshadweep

facts.famousFood: Mus Kavaab (Tuna Fish Curry), Octopus Fry, Coconut Rice

territories.history: Lakshadweep is India’s smallest Union Territory, consisting of 36 coral islands in the Arabian Sea. The name means “a hundred thousand islands.” These islands were historically influenced by Arab traders, and Islam spread early here. It became a Union Territory in 1956. The islands are known for their pristine ecology, lagoons, and marine life, and efforts are ongoing to develop them as a sustainable eco-tourism zone.

touristPlaces.name: Agatti Island
touristPlaces.description: Gateway to Lakshadweep with turquoise lagoons and coral reefs perfect for snorkeling.

touristPlaces.name: Bangaram Atoll
touristPlaces.description: Uninhabited island with white sandy beaches and spectacular marine life.

touristPlaces.name: Kavaratti Island
touristPlaces.description: Capital island known for its marine aquarium and pristine beaches.

territories.name: Jammu & Kashmir

facts.famousFood: Rogan Josh, Gushtaba, Yakhni, Kashmiri Pulao

territories.history: Jammu and Kashmir was a princely state that acceded to India in October 1947 under Maharaja Hari Singh following a tribal invasion from Pakistan. It enjoyed special autonomy under Article 370, which was abrogated on August 5, 2019, leading to the bifurcation of the state into two Union Territories—Jammu and Kashmir (with a legislative assembly) and Ladakh (without legislature). Since October 31, 2019, Jammu and Kashmir has been under the direct administration of the Central Government, with provisions for holding elections to enable local governance.

touristPlaces.name: Dal Lake
touristPlaces.description: Famous for its houseboats and shikara rides with mountain views.

touristPlaces.description: Popular skiing destination with the world's highest gondola ride.
